sentences.text: The '''UEFA Euro 2024 final''' was a Association football|football match that determined the winners of UEFA Euro 2024. The match was the seventeenth List of UEFA European Championship finals|final of the UEFA European Championship|European Championship, a quadrennial tournament contested by the men's national teams of the member associations of UEFA to decide the champions of Europe. The match was held at the Olympiastadion (Berlin)|Olympiastadion in Berlin, Germany, on 14 July 2024, and was contested by Spain national football team|Spain, in their fifth final, and England national football team|England, in their second final, but their first appearance in a major men's tournament final held outside their home country. Following their defeat in the UEFA Euro 2020 final|previous final, England also became the fourth different side to appear in two consecutive Euro finals, after the Soviet Union national football team|Soviet Union (1960 European Nations' Cup final|1960 and 1964 European Nations' Cup final|1964), West Germany national football team results|West Germany (UEFA Euro 1972 final|1972, UEFA Euro 1976 final|1976 and UEFA Euro 1980 final|1980), unified Germany (UEFA Euro 1992 final|1992 and UEFA Euro 1996 final|1996), and Spain (UEFA Euro 2008 final|2008 and UEFA Euro 2012 final|2012).

references.text: <ref>{{cite web |title=Euro 2024 final: England must be 'tactically perfect' to beat Spain – Gareth Southgate|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/articles/cjerlqzvx73o |website=BBC Sport |access-date=12 July 2024 |date=11 July 2024}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web |url=https://editorial.uefa.com/resources/0288-1999ab91ad50-899894098aed-1000/uefa_euro_2024_match_schedule.pdf |title=UEFA Euro 2024 match schedule |website=UEFA |publisher=Union of European Football Associations |access-date=3 December 2023}}</ref>

sentences.text: Spain won all seven matches they played in the competition, the first side to accomplish this since France national football team|France won five out of five in UEFA Euro 1984|1984, and set a new record for most goals scored in a single European Championship, with fifteen. England, meanwhile, became the first side to lose consecutive finals. This was also the first time both finalists conceded in every knockout game contested since the tournament's expansion in UEFA Euro 1980|1980.

references.text: <ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.uefa.com/euro2024/news/028f-1b5e5c2b7b67-d5faab9be20b-1000/ |title=Spain 2–1 England: Late Oyarzabal winner earns La Roja record fourth EURO crown |work=UEFA |publisher=Union of European Football Associations |date=14 July 2024 |access-date=14 July 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text: The final was held at the Olympiastadion (Berlin)|Olympiastadion in Berlin, Germany, located in Westend (Berlin)|Westend of the Charlottenburg-Wilmersdorf|borough of Charlottenburg-Wilmersdorf. On 27 September 2018, UEFA announced the 2024 tournament would be held in Germany after they had defeated Turkey in the host selection vote in Nyon, Switzerland. The Olympiastadion was chosen as the final venue of the tournament by the UEFA Executive Committee in May 2022, where it was announced it would also host three group stage matches, a round of 16 match, and a quarter-final match in the tournament.

references.text: <ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.uefa.com/news-media/news/0249-0f8e640dc5e1-2ebf8efacf63-1000--germany-to-host-uefa-euro-2024/ |title=Germany to host UEFA EURO 2024 |publisher=UEFA |website=UEFA|date=27 September 2018}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/45666950 |title=Euro 2024: Germany beats Turkey to host tournament |date=27 September 2018 |website=BBC Sport|access-date=27 September 2018}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web|title=Uefa EURO 2024 Final in the Olympiade stadion Berlin, Six Games in the Capital|publisher=Olympiastadion Berlin |url=https://olympiastadion.berlin/en/news/uefa-euro-2024-final-in-the-olympiastadion-berlin/|access-date=3 December 2023|date=20 May 2022}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.uefa.com/euro2024/news/0273-14ac084902cc-9ef59ec61319-1000--euro-2024-host-cities-and-stadiums/ |title=EURO 2024 host cities: Venue guide |website=UEFA |year=2022 |access-date=12 May 2022 }}</ref>

sentences.text: The Olympiastadion opened in 1936 on the Olympiapark Berlin which served specifically for the 1936 Summer Olympics. The stadium is owned by the state of Berlin and has been the Home (sports)|home stadium of football club Hertha BSC since 1963. The Germany national football team|Germany national team has also occasionally played its home matches at the stadium. The Olympiastadion has also hosted several significant matches, including several matches in the 1974 FIFA World Cup|1974 and 2006 FIFA World Cup|2006 World Cups, the latter of which included the 2006 FIFA World Cup final|final between Italy national football team|Italy and France national football team|France. It has been the venue of every List of DFB-Pokal finals|final of the DFB-Pokal since 1985. It also served as the 2011 FIFA Women's World Cup Group A#Germany vs Canada|official opening match venue for the 2011 FIFA Women's World Cup as well as the 2015 UEFA Champions League final between FC Barcelona|Barcelona and Juventus FC|Juventus.

references.text: <ref>{{cite web | title=Olympic Stadium | website=Berlin.de | date=11 May 2022 | url=https://www.berlin.de/en/attractions-and-sights/3560924-3104052-olympic-stadium.en.html | access-date=11 July 2024}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/germany2006/matches/match/97410064/ |title=Italy – France |website=FIFA.com |publisher=Fédération Internationale de Football Association |access-date=9 August 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200412060648/https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/germany2006/matches/match/97410064/ |archive-date=12 April 2020 |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: Spain qualified for the tournament as UEFA Euro 2024 qualifying Group A|qualifying Group A winners, winning seven of their eight matches with their only loss coming against Scotland national football team|Scotland. They were drawn into UEFA Euro 2024 Group B|Group B along with Croatia national football team|Croatia, UEFA Euro 2020 final|current holders Italy national football team|Italy and Albania national football team|Albania. Spain opened their campaign with a 3–0 win over Croatia at the Olympiastadion (Berlin)|Olympiastadion, Álvaro Morata opened the scoring for Spain in the 29th minute, then Fabián Ruiz doubled their advantage in the 32nd minute and Dani Carvajal then added a third for Spain in the 47th minute. By starting this match, Lamine Yamal became the youngest player to make an appearance at a UEFA European Championship final tournament. Spain then played title holders and Italy–Spain football rivalry|arch-rivals, Italy at the Arena AufSchalke winning 1–0 with the sole goal coming from a Riccardo Calafiori own goal in the 55th minute. They then rounded off their group stage campaign with another 1–0 win over Albania at the Merkur Spiel-Arena with the lone goal scored by Ferran Torres in the 13th minute, with Spain manager Luis de la Fuente (footballer, born 1961)|Luis de la Fuente making wholesale changes to the starting eleven due to Spain having already secured top-spot in their group.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |title=Spain 3–0 Croatia {{!}} UEFA EURO 2024 |url=https://www.uefa.com/uefaeuro/match/2036163--spain-vs-croatia/ |access-date=10 July 2024 |website=UEFA |publisher=Union of European Football Associations}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |date=15 June 2024 |title=Lamine Yamal sets new record as youngest player to feature at a UEFA European Championship |url=https://www.uefa.com/euro2024/news/0255-0d9f33ac425a-2e8c3765087b-1000/ |access-date=10 July 2024 |website=UEFA |publisher=Union of European Football Associations}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |title=Spain 1–0 Italy {{!}} UEFA EURO 2024 |url=https://www.uefa.com/uefaeuro/match/2036175--spain-vs-italy/ |access-date=10 July 2024 |website=UEFA |publisher=Union of European Football Associations}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |title=Albania 0–1 Spain {{!}} UEFA EURO 2024 |url=https://www.uefa.com/uefaeuro/match/2036187--albania-vs-spain/ |access-date=10 July 2024 |website=UEFA |publisher=Union of European Football Associations}}</ref>

sentences.text: In the knockout stage, Spain played the third-placed team from UEFA Euro 2024 Group F|Group F in the Round of 16, Georgia national football team|Georgia – who were making their European Championship debut – at the RheinEnergieStadion where Spain won 4–1 with goals for the Spanish from Rodri (footballer, born 1996)|Rodri in the 39th minute, Fabián in the 51st minute, Nico Williams in the 75th minute and Dani Olmo in the 83rd minute. Robin Le Normand scored an own goal which acted as a consolation goal for Georgia in the 18th minute. In the quarter-finals, Spain played hosts Germany national football team|Germany at the MHPArena, in a re-match of the UEFA Euro 2008 final, which Spain won 1–0. This time Spain won again 2–1 Overtime (sports)#Association football|after extra time with Olmo opening the scoring for Spain in the 51st minute, Florian Wirtz then equalised for Germany in the 89th minute. Mikel Merino scored with a header in the 119th minute to send Spain through to the semi-finals and eliminate Julian Nagelsmann's hosts at the last-eight stage. In the semi-finals, Spain played 2022 FIFA World Cup runners-up, France national football team|France at the Allianz Arena, in a re-match of both the UEFA Euro 1984 final and the 2021 UEFA Nations League final, both of which France won. Spain won this time with Randal Kolo Muani opening the scoring for the French with a header in the 9th minute, but Yamal then equalised for the Spanish in the 21st minute with a shot to the left corner from outside the penalty area, Olmo then scored the winner for Spain in the 25th minute – this was originally given as a Jules Koundé own goal but after a review was given to Olmo – this sent Spain through to their first List of UEFA European Championship finals|UEFA European Championship final since the UEFA Euro 2012 final against Italy which they won 4–0. Yamal also became the youngest player to score in a UEFA European Championship.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |title=Spain 4–1 Georgia {{!}} UEFA EURO 2024 |url=https://www.uefa.com/uefaeuro/match/2036199--spain-vs-georgia/ |access-date=10 July 2024 |website=UEFA |publisher=Union of European Football Associations}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |title=Spain 2–1 Germany {{!}} UEFA EURO 2024 |url=https://www.uefa.com/uefaeuro/match/2036205--spain-vs-germany/ |access-date=10 July 2024 |website=UEFA |publisher=Union of European Football Associations}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |title=Spain 2–1 France {{!}} UEFA EURO 2024 |url=https://www.uefa.com/uefaeuro/match/2036209--spain-vs-france/ |access-date=10 July 2024 |website=UEFA |publisher=Union of European Football Associations}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |date=9 July 2024 |title=Lamine Yamal: Spain 'superstar' makes his mark at Euro 2024 |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/articles/cx82xyynw17o |access-date=10 July 2024 |website=BBC Sport }}</ref>

sentences.text: England qualified for the tournament as UEFA Euro 2024 qualifying Group C|Group C winners, winning six of their eight qualification matches. England were drawn into UEFA Euro 2024 Group C|Group C along with Serbia national football team|Serbia, Denmark national football team|Denmark, and Slovenia national football team|Slovenia. England opened their campaign with a 1–0 win over Serbia at the Arena AufSchalke, with Jude Bellingham scoring with a header in the 13th minute. England then played Denmark at the Waldstadion (Frankfurt)|Waldstadion, in a re-match of the semi-final at the previous European Championships which England won 2–1 Overtime (sports)#Association football|after extra time. This time it ended in a 1–1 draw. Harry Kane scored early on in the 18th minute, but Denmark's Morten Hjulmand equalised with a low shot to the corner before half time in the 34th minute. England finished the group stage by facing Slovenia at the RheinEnergieStadion, which ended goalless. England finished top of the group with five points, and progressed to the knockout stage to play a third place team from one of UEFA Euro 2024 Group D|Groups D, UEFA Euro 2024 Group E|E, or UEFA Euro 2024 Group F|F.<ref name="top2" />

references.text: <ref>{{cite web | title=Euro 2024: Who has qualified? Who is in the play-offs? Who has failed to qualify? | website=BBC Sport | date=7 September 2023 | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/66715849 | access-date=11 July 2024}}</ref>
<ref>{{cite web |date=15 June 2024 |title=England 1–0 Serbia |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/live/cz992dxd4xwt |access-date=11 July 2024 |website=BBC Sport}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web |date=19 June 2024 |title=England 1–1 Denmark: England miss chance to reach last 16 after frustrating draw in Frankfurt |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/live/c5110ej8g31t |access-date=11 July 2024 |website=BBC Sport}}</ref>

<ref name="top2">{{cite web |date=24 June 2024 |title=England 0–0 Slovenia: England frustrated in Slovenia draw but still top group |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/live/c8000g2nj98t |access-date=11 July 2024 |website=BBC Sport}}</ref>

sentences.text: In the knockout stage, England played the third-placed team from Group E in the round of 16, Slovakia national football team|Slovakia at the Arena AufSchalke where England won 2–1. Ivan Schranz opened the scoring for Slovakia in the 25th minute. At the end of the second half, England were seconds away from being knocked out of the competition before Bellingham's bicycle kick goal in the 5th minute of added time sent the game into Overtime (sports)#Association football|extra time. Kane immediately scored with a header after extra time started, in the 91st minute. In the quarter-finals, England played Switzerland national football team|Switzerland at the Merkur Spiel-Arena, where they drew 1–1 Overtime (sports)#Association football|after extra time, with Breel Embolo opening the scoring for Switzerland in the 75th minute and Bukayo Saka then equalising for England in the 80th minute when he cut in from the right before shooting low to the left corner of the net. With the scores still level after extra time, the match went to a Penalty shootout|penalty shoot-out, which England won 5–3 with Cole Palmer, Bellingham, Saka, Ivan Toney and Trent Alexander-Arnold all converting their penalties for England and Fabian Schär, Xherdan Shaqiri and Zeki Amdouni all converting their penalty kicks for Switzerland. Only Manuel Akanji missed the opening Switzerland penalty, which was saved by England goalkeeper Jordan Pickford. In the semi-finals, England played the Netherlands national football team|Netherlands at the Westfalenstadion where England won 2–1. Xavi Simons opened the scoring for the Dutch in the 7th minute. Kane then equalised after a controversial penalty kick was awarded for a foul on him by Denzel Dumfries following a video assistant referee review in the 18th minute. England then won the game very late on when Palmer assisted Ollie Watkins to score in the 90th minute, sending them through to their first major tournament final outside of their home country, and their second consecutive European Championship final after appearing in the UEFA Euro 2020 final at Wembley Stadium which they lost to Italy national football team|Italy.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |title=England 2–1 Slovakia {{!}} UEFA EURO 2024 |url=https://www.uefa.com/uefaeuro/match/2036200--england-vs-slovakia/ |access-date=11 July 2024|date=30 June 2024 |website=UEFA |publisher=Union of European Football Associations}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |title=England 1–1 Switzerland {{!}} UEFA EURO 2024 |url=https://www.uefa.com/uefaeuro/match/2036208--england-vs-switzerland/ |access-date=11 July 2024|date=6 July 2024 |website=UEFA |publisher=Union of European Football Associations}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |title=Netherlands 1–2 England {{!}} UEFA EURO 2024 |url=https://www.uefa.com/uefaeuro/match/2036210--netherlands-vs-england/ |access-date=11 July 2024|date=10 July 2024 |website=UEFA |publisher=Union of European Football Associations}}</ref>

sentences.text: Their most recent encounter in a senior men's major tournament was the UEFA Euro 1996 knockout stage#Spain vs England|Euro 1996 quarter-final, which England won 4–2 on penalties after a 0–0 draw. England's manager Gareth Southgate was a starting centre back for The Three Lions in that game. Spain's only victory over England in a major tournament was a 1–0 win in the 1950 FIFA World Cup Group 2#Spain vs England|1950 FIFA World Cup group stage match.

references.text: <ref name="prev">{{cite web | title=Previous meetings between England and Spain ahead of Euro 2024 final | website=The Independent | date=11 July 2024 | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/england-spain-david-seaman-stuart-pearce-ollie-watkins-b2577902.html | access-date=11 July 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text: Across men's and women's, youth and senior football, it is the fourth England–Spain tournament final in just over a year, after the 2023 UEFA European Under-21 Championship final, the 2023 FIFA Women's World Cup final and the 2024 UEFA Women's Under-17 Championship#Final|2024 UEFA Women's Under-17 Championship final. The 2023 Under-21 Championship final was won 1–0 by England and featured Álex Baena (for Spain), Cole Palmer and Anthony Gordon (footballer)|Anthony Gordon (both for England), who were all in the squads for Euro 2024.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news |last=Culpepper |first=Chuck |date=19 August 2023|title=Shiny and new, it's England and Spain for a World Cup final that fits |language=en-US |newspaper=The Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/2023/08/19/england-spain-womens-world-cup-final-preview/ |access-date=21 August 2023|issn=0190-8286}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web | last=Howell | first=Alex | title=England U21 1–0 Spain U21: England win Under-21 Euros for first time in 39 years | website=BBC Sport | date=7 July 2023 | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/66127349 | access-date=11 July 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text: The match was attended by William, Prince of Wales|Prince William, the heir apparent to the Monarchy of the United Kingdom|British throne and President of the The Football Association|Football Association, together with his elder son Prince George of Wales|Prince George. He also attended the previous tournament's final at Wembley and the UEFA Women's Euro 2022 final|Women's Euro 2022 final at the same venue and awarded winner's medals to the victorious England women's team afterwards. Downing Street also confirmed that Sir Keir Starmer, the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, would also attend. He was accompanied by Lisa Nandy, the Secretary of State for Culture, Media and Sport, and Debbie Hewitt, chairwoman of the Football Association.<ref name=celebs/>

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-07-14 |title=William and George see England heartbreak at Euro 2024 final |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c3gw54p1jeno |access-date=2024-07-14 |website=BBC News |language=en-GB}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |last1=Hollie |first1=Cole |title=Prince William to attend Euro 2024 final in Berlin |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/cw5ypd3v7ngo |access-date=13 July 2024 |work=BBC News |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=12 July 2024 }}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |last1=Rhoden-Paul |first1=André |title=Euro 2024: I don't want to jinx it, Starmer says about Euros bank holiday |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/cd197zdxv52o |access-date=13 July 2024 |work=BBC News |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=11 July 2024 }}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web | last=Boffey | first=Daniel | title=Starmer says England have 'made country proud' as fans arrive in Berlin for Euros final | website=the Guardian | date=14 July 2024 | url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/article/2024/jul/14/euro-2024-starmer-fans-arrive-in-berlin | access-date=15 July 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text: From Spain, both King Felipe VI and his younger daughter, Infanta Sofía of Spain|Infanta Sofía, attended the match. King Felipe was one of the authorities who greeted the players at the awards ceremony and the one who presented the trophy to the champions. Both royals later joined the Spanish team's celebrations. Pedro Sánchez, Prime Minister of Spain, also attended, along with the Ministry of Education (Spain)|Minister of Education, Vocational Training and Sports, Pilar Alegría.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news |last=Smith |first=Rory |date=2024-07-14 |title=A New Prince Leads Spain as It Rules European Soccer Again |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2024/07/14/world/europe/euro-2024-final-spain-lamine-yamal.html |access-date=2024-07-15 |work=The New York Times |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}}</ref>

sentences.text: Relevant German authorities such as the President of Germany, Frank-Walter Steinmeier, the German Chancellor, Olaf Scholz, and the president of the Bundestag, Bärbel Bas, were also present.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |last=Rastreador |first=El |date=2024-07-14 |title=El 'selfie' de Sánchez, Scholz y Starmer en la final de la Eurocopa: "¡Esperamos con impaciencia!" |url=https://www.eldiario.es/rastreador/selfie-sanchez-scholz-starmer-final-eurocopa-esperamos-impaciencia_132_11523428.html |access-date=2024-07-15 |website=ElDiario.es |language=es}}</ref>

sentences.text: Also present were Gareth Bale, Lando Norris, David Villa, Xavi (footballer, born 1980)|Xavi, Andrés Iniesta, Harry Styles, Danny Dyer and Dani Dyer.

sentences.text: Before the match started, a closing ceremony was organised by UEFA, which started at 20:45 Central European Time|local time (19:45 Coordinated Universal Time|UTC). Its theme was to honour the value of the handshake. Two groups from the Berlin-based Lunatix dance company took the spotlight, forming into a double "human wall" in a dance routine, which used the performers' hands and arms to create synchronised movements, before pyrotechnics got underway. After the handshake and the dance, Italian music group Meduza (producers)|Meduza, American pop rock band OneRepublic and German pop singer Leony performed "Fire (Meduza, OneRepublic and Leony song)|Fire", the List of UEFA European Championship songs and anthems|official song of UEFA Euro 2024.

references.text: <ref>{{cite web |title=Guide to Berlin for the European Championships Final |url=https://rfef.es/en/noticias/guide-to-berlin-for-the-european-championships-final |access-date=15 February 2025}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pulsesports.co.ke/football/story/euro-2024-breathtaking-photos-from-the-colourful-closing-ceremony-2024071419405781568|title=Euro 2024: Breathtaking Photos from the colourful closing ceremony|website=pulsesports.co.ke|date=14 July 2024|first=Eric|last=Munene|accessdate=15 July 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 11 July 2024, the UEFA Referees Committee announced that France|French referee François Letexier, who refereed three other games at Euro 2024, would be the referee for the final. At 35, he was the youngest referee of a European Championship final. Letexier was joined by Cyril Mugnier and Mehdi Rahmouni as assistant referees, while Poland|Polish referee Szymon Marciniak was the fourth official. The video assistant referees (VAR) were French official Jérôme Brisard, assisted by fellow Frenchman Willy Delajod and supported by Italy|Italian referee Massimiliano Irrati. Polish referee Tomasz Listkiewicz was the reserve assistant referee.<ref name="referees"/>

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=11 July 2024 |title=French referee François Letexier picked to handle Spain-England final of Euro 2024 |url=https://apnews.com/article/euro-final-referee-439818c4b928b26e64e80eebf5b06922 |access-date=11 July 2024 |publisher=Associated Press }}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.uefa.com/euro2024/news/028f-1b5b4f59b6ad-d82536d24085-1000--euro-2024-final-referee-letexier-primed-for-action/|title=EURO 2024 final referee Letexier primed for action|date=13 July 2024|access-date=14 July 2024|website=UEFA}}</ref>

sentences.text: Spain won a corner in the early minutes, which was cleared by England, before Spain consolidated possession with frequent passes and opportunities created by Nico Williams. England then won a free kick after a foul on Jude Bellingham in about the tenth minute, which Luke Shaw sent towards the box; a foul on Aymeric Laporte during this play saw possession given to Spain, and Williams again took the ball to the box. In the opening exchanges, while England prevented Spain from getting a shot on target, they also saw little of the ball and struggled when on it, while Spain appeared more settled and were able to play through the lines. England then started to play better for a period after the fifteenth minute, with opportunities created by Bukayo Saka. Targeting the same area, behind Spanish defender Marc Cucurella, England won the ball in the 21st minute but quickly lost it again under pressure from Dani Olmo. Olmo sent the ball over to Lamine Yamal, who had been quieter up to this point with Spain attacking on the other side. Yamal's shot was blocked for a corner, off which England gained possession and launched a counter-attack that was ended when Dani Carvajal fouled Saka.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name="Athletic" /> ''The Guardian'' said the foul was cynical, and noted that Carvajal made a crying gesture towards England players afterwards when England captain Harry Kane was intervening with the referee about the lack of Yellow card (association football)|yellow card on Carvajal.<ref name=":0" /> Shaw sent the free kick to the edge of the area; Kane got the ball but followed through, losing it and fouling Fabián Ruiz. Kane was shown a yellow card,<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name="Athletic" /> which Marca (newspaper)|''Marca'' said was deserved.<ref name=":1" /> A few minutes later, Ruiz had a shot towards goal that ran through to the goalkeeper.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name="Athletic" />

sentences.text:
.]]
UEFA president Aleksander Čeferin was present on the pitch stage during the awards ceremony to hand out the medals and present the trophy to Spanish captain Álvaro Morata. He was joined by King of Spain Felipe VI. Giorgio Chiellini, Italy's winning Euro 2020 captain and a former teammate of Morata, brought the trophy onto the pitch for the ceremony. Spain became the first European champions to have won all their group and knockout matches without any penalty shootouts since France national football team|France in UEFA Euro 1984|1984.

references.text: <ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.football-espana.net/2024/07/15/alvaro-morata-andres-iniesta-saving-spain-career-euro-2024|title=Alvaro Morata hints at Andres Iniesta saving his Spain career ahead of Euro 2024|first=Feargal|last=Brennan|date=15 July 2024|accessdate=15 July 2024|work=Football Espana}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news|url=https://football-italia.net/video-chiellini-hands-back-italys-european/|title=Video: Chiellini hands back Italy's European Championship trophy|first=Susy|last=Campanale|work=Football Italia|date=14 July 2024|accessdate=15 July 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text: Spanish winger Nico Williams was named as the man of the match, Spain's Lamine Yamal, who turned 17 the day before the final, was named as the UEFA European Championship awards#Young Player of the Tournament|UEFA Young Player of the Tournament, making him the youngest ever player to feature in a UEFA Euro or FIFA World Cup showpiece. The Spanish team celebrated their victory with a parade through Madrid on an open-top bus to Plaza de Cibeles the day after the final on 15 July, attended by thousands. The team met with King Felipe VI, the Spanish royal family and the Prime Minister of Spain Pedro Sánchez. During the celebrations, players Rodri (footballer, born 1996)|Rodri and Álvaro Morata chanted that Gibraltar is Spanish, leading to condemnation from the Government of Gibraltar and a formal complaint to UEFA from the Gibraltar Football Association.

references.text: <ref name="MOTM"/> and his teammate Rodri (footballer, born 1996)|Rodri was named as the UEFA European Championship awards#Player of the Tournament|UEFA European Championship Player of the Tournament.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.uefa.com/euro2024/news/028f-1b5e5d20015d-63e00bbe0723-1000--rodri-named-euro-2024-player-of-the-tournament/|title=Rodri named EURO 2024 Player of the Tournament|website=UEFA|publisher=Union of European Football Associations|date=14 July 2024|access-date=15 July 2024}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.uefa.com/euro2024/news/028f-1b5e5e91b6e6-b9784b9e13fb-1000--lamine-yamal-named-euro-2024-young-player-of-the-tournament/|title=Lamine Yamal named EURO 2024 Young Player of the Tournament|website=UEFA|publisher=Union of European Football Associations|date=14 July 2024|access-date=15 July 2024}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20240715-spain-celebrates-euro-2024-heroes|title=Spain celebrates Euro 2024 heroes|work=France 24|date=15 July 2024|accessdate=15 July 2024}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/articles/cd167yxv706o|title=Fans celebrate after Spain's royal welcome in Madrid|work=BBC Sport|date=15 July 2024|accessdate=15 July 2024}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.euronews.com/my-europe/2024/07/15/spanish-national-football-team-returns-to-madrid-to-celebrate-euro-2024-win|title=Spanish national football team returns to Madrid to celebrate Euro 2024 win|work=Euronews|date=15 July 2024|accessdate=15 July 2024}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |last1=Ignacio |first1=Stephen |title=Gibraltar FA to make formal complaint after Spanish national team chants 'Gibraltar Español' |url=https://www.chronicle.gi/gibraltar-fa-to-make-formal-complaint-after-spanish-national-team-chants-gibraltar-espanol/ |access-date=16 July 2024 |work=Gibraltar Chronicle |date=16 July 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text: Emlyn Begley of BBC Sport wrote that Spain's triumph was unanimously seen as "fully deserved", as the team had won all seven games without going to a penalty shootout, against difficult opposition. English pundits including Chris Sutton, Gary Lineker, Micah Richards and Alan Shearer praised Spain for playing attacking football and working as a team, while considering England to be a selection of individuals rather than a team. Gary Neville said "it feels like a never-ending story where we just can't get over the line" and described a sense of "rinse and repeat" of England failing to keep the ball well enough at major championships. Spanish football journalist Guillem Balagué praised Spain manager Luis de la Fuente (footballer, born 1961)|Luis de la Fuente for winning the competition with players he had managed to under-19 and under-21 titles in the 2010s. adding "these players have made history and they still have a long way to go" and that "this group can keep growing because they do not tire of hard work, competing and trying to win." Spain match-winner Mikel Oyarzabal said he was lucky enough to give the victory, adding "I have done my job. I did what I had to do at every moment to try to help", while defender Marc Cucurella added: "We deserved it from the start. Not many people backed us, but we kept quiet and did our job, which is to play football."

references.text: <ref name=begley>{{cite news |last1=Begley |first1=Emlyn |title='A good thing for football' – Spain's victory caps off perfect campaign |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/articles/cv2gvreml2ko |access-date=15 July 2024 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 July 2024}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web |last=Shearer |first=Alan |title=Defeat may be Southgate's last - but he'd leave England with head high |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/articles/c06kn3x8dpgo |access-date=18 July 2024 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 July 2024}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web |last=Morgan |first=Tom |title=Gary Neville: England failure feels like never-ending story |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2024/07/14/gary-neville-england-failure-spain-euro-2024-final-itv/ |access-date=18 July 2024 |publisher=The Daily Telegraph |date=14 July 2024}}</ref>

<ref name=begley/> De la Fuente praised his side and said they had been "infallible" and did "everything right",<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/video/2024/jul/15/we-have-earned-this-spain-coach-luis-de-la-fuente-hails-euro-2024-victory-over-england-video|title='We have earned this': Spain coach Luis de la Fuente hails Euro 2024 victory over England – video|work=The Guardian|date=15 July 2024|accessdate=15 July 2024}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Sports/euro-2024-spain-coach-hails-historymakers-after-final/story?id=111944426|title=Euro 2024: Spain coach hails historymakers after final win|work=ABC News|first=Sam|last=Marsden|date=15 July 2024|accessdate=15 July 2024}}</ref>

<ref name="reaction">{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/sports/soccer/reaction-spains-victory-over-england-euro-2024-final-2024-07-14/|title=Reaction to Spain's victory over England in Euro 2024 final|work=Reuters|date=14 July 2024|accessdate=18 July 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text: England manager Gareth Southgate praised his team for their efforts but admitted they "fell short", saying "we had an opportunity to win and we haven't been able to take it". Immediately after the game, Southgate said that he could not answer whether it would be his final match. Captain Harry Kane said they had done well to get back into the game, adding "We could have used that momentum to push on", concluding: "It's as painful as it could be in a football match." King Charles III congratulated the England team in a letter addressed to Southgate, calling it "a really great achievement in itself" to reach the final. Southgate resigned two days after the final.

references.text: <ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/video/2024/jul/15/gareth-southgate-reaction-england-euro-2024-final-video|title='We fell short': Southgate on England's loss to Spain in Euro 2024 final – video|work=The Guardian|date=15 July 2024|accessdate=15 July 2024}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |last1=Sanders |first1=Emma |title=Southgate says 'now not the time' to decide future |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/articles/cw4ywnd9j2go |access-date=15 July 2024 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 July 2024}}</ref>

<ref name="reaction"/> Jude Bellingham said they had sacrificed a lot throughout the last weeks and admitted feeling "mentally and physically exhausted" and "absolutely dead".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2024/07/15/england-euros-final-heartbreak-southgate-lineker-live/|title=Kane and Bellingham admit England players 'mentally and physically exhausted'|work=The Telegraph|first=Mike|last=McGrath|date=15 July 2024|accessdate=18 July 2024|url-access=subscription|quote=It’s difficult on the body – mentally and physically you are exhausted. But for our country we wanted to give everything.}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |last1=Rufo |first1=Yasmin |title=Hold your heads high, King tells Southgate and team |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/c3gw54p1jeno |access-date=15 July 2024 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 July 2024}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |title=Southgate resigns after England's Euro 2024 loss |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/articles/c978e37ld7ro |access-date=16 July 2024 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 July 2024}}</ref>
